ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar of less than 10 students daily, and weekly one-on-one virtual meetings with a TF.
There were also occasional asynchronous classes and recorded assignments.
n/a
Included live virtual tutorials and asynchronous sessions

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: a lotta japanese!
While I obviously improved my Japanese skills and learned more grammar and vocabulary, I also greatly improved my understanding of Japanese culture.
I developed my Japanese speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. This class also serves an introduction to the specifics of Japanese pronunciation.
reading and writing in Japanese
Japanese vocabulary, registers, grammar, pronunciation, reading, writing, and listening

I greatly developed my conversational abilities. We learned more about different filler words and conventions that aided in being able to converse more naturally. We learned a ton of kanji and extremely useful grammar as well. Overall, I'd say this class greatly improved my Japanese.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths of this course are the amount of interaction between professor and students, the amount of material covered, and the weekly one-on-one meetings with a TF.
Although we were introduced to pronunciation specifics in this class, I would have liked even more practice with the pronunciation before the quizzes.
in-class activities are very helpful.

Instruction was excellent given the online format. Use of breakout rooms, google slides, and other interactive media during class was effective for Zoom. Canvas page was well-organized for student use and grades always returned promptly. Homework load occasionally felt heavy.

I can think of very little weaknesses. The course was perfectly balanced to include practices in all domains. I think maybe changing the structure of the asynchronous portions to include a bit less group work might be useful, but overall, I really enjoy working with a partner. It was just difficult sometimes to align with the timing given the lack of in-person classes.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was difficult to be involved in the class whenever there was internet difficulties. While I do not think this should be used instead of attending class, a fully online version of some lessons would be convenient. The professor could make a limit to these, such as one every two weeks or seven in total.
Asynchronous classes were a good chance to practice individual reading and writing skills.
Course was well-adapted to the format. Simultaneous use of slides and zoom made it generally easy to keep up in breakout rooms without immediate access to the instructor.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are really interested in learning Japanese, yes, hands down.
Absolutely. This class is strongly suggested to those who would enjoy learning Japanese and more about Japan culture.

Yes I would recommend this course to other students. Despite taking it remotely, I still found it enjoyable. Language tables and breakout rooms still allowed a lot of interaction between my classmates, Professor Nishimura, and I.
yes, it's very helpful for students interested in Japanese language and culture.
One of the best online courses I have taken. I would still recommend in-person instruction, but given the COVID circumstances I would recommend it.
